posts.name: Paul Garrett
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone!  Thanks to @aph5 , I was able to construct the 4 badges for the FIRST badging system with the intention of using if for my team.  This is not official but an attempt to help our programmers along as they continue through the program (programming badges are not provided on firstbadges.com ).  I have attempted to use Bloom‚Äôs Taxonomy as an outline, as FIRST asks us to do, and I‚Äôm wondering if I did that correctly.

I would appreciate any feedback you have.  I‚Äôve linked the documents below with comment access, so feel free to let me know what you think!

Programming Level 1

Programming Level 2

Programming Level 3

Programming Level 4

posts.name: Jack
posts.cooked: The focus on command-based in level 3 & 4 nullifies this project‚Äôs usefulness for teams using non-command-based.

posts.name: Paul Garrett
posts.cooked: That‚Äôs true, what would you suggest fills the space of those requirements?  I am so used to seeing teams using command-based after a certain point.

posts.name: Jack
posts.cooked: There are two ways I see of doing it. First is replacing the requirement with a more helpful measurement of learning that can be applied to any setup. The second is having two different pathways, so the requirements involve either doing command-based or other.

posts.name: Paul Garrett
posts.cooked: Absolutely, I was thinking of offering different paths.  I meant to say, what would you specifically put there?  The WPI docs basically lead into command-based which is why I really used  it.

posts.name: Mykah
posts.cooked:
To add on to the above, I agree that having such a sole focus on Command-Based is doing a large disservice to those teams that do not make use of it, and can also force students into a mindset of believing Command-Based to be the only option. However, I do believe having Command-Based be required at at-least some level, its a very useful thing, as it forces the student to learn more about the options available to them.

Personally, I‚Äôd say to leave Level 3 either largely unchanged, OR add more requirements to include BOTH Command-Based and Timed Robot Understanding and expand the compare and contrasting criteria. Regardless of which you go for though, I‚Äôd also leave out the and evaluate the advantages the former has. bit as this does give the connotation that Command-Based is ‚Äòbetter than Timed Robot‚Äô, which is both wrong and antithetical to the goal of expanding knowledge for the badge participant.

Now level 4 is a different beast. and personally I‚Äôd say ‚Äúreduce‚Äù the first requirement to simply ‚ÄúProgram a full Competition Robot‚Äù and don‚Äôt include any requirement of Command-Based or TimedRobot.

For the second Level 4 requirement, I say we turn that into ‚ÄúAdvanced Robot Programming‚Äù and change it into another ‚ÄúPick One‚Äù to ‚Äúexpand‚Äù the base competition robot code requirement above, and have Command-Based and Non-CB options.

posts.name: Curt Rozeboom
posts.cooked:
I‚Äôd like to throw out my team‚Äôs approach to this as well, just as an example to draw from. I saw your original post on badges and got my team interested in using something like it as a training motivational approach. I‚Äôd had a similar loose system for programming that I‚Äôd developed a few years ago and put it together into something more structured as a result. It follows the pedagogical approach from Bloom (as much as I could) as well. I‚Äôm already taking a few ideas from yours to add to ours.

Reading through the critiques offered in previous posts, I‚Äôd say that the same critiques could be leveled at my approach; it‚Äôs Java oriented, Command-based oriented and also I‚Äôve really tuned it to what I think would best fit our particular team culture and resources. ( https://www.tigerdynasty.org/wiki/ ) However, those aspects really could be stripped away and replaced with ‚Äúyour team‚Äôs‚Äù preferred language (Labview/C++/Java/Python/ROS/Kotlin/etc) and simply learning your own team‚Äôs robot design patterns and approach. I‚Äôve drawn from other resources that I‚Äôve come across over the years, but also wanted it really heavily rooted it in having the students learn directly from docs.wpilib.org .

There‚Äôs such a wide array of possible approaches to programming that it‚Äôs hard to capture it in a general badge program without stripping away so much that it just becomes very amorphous and hard to use directly. This requires teams to really ‚Äòfill-in-the-blanks‚Äô for their own approach, which isn‚Äôt necessarily a bad thing either. There‚Äôs definitely a trade-off between that and having something everyone can commonly use without adaptation, though.

posts.name: Paul Garrett
posts.cooked:
I attempted to incorporate all the suggestions that were given above.  This was going to be for our team to use based on our experience and success in the past.  I‚Äôm happy I can change it for a general template for any team to use, I am just unsure of how possible that is but I‚Äôm going to do my best!  Let me know what you think of the changes:

Programming Level 1

Programming Level 2

Programming Level 3

Programming Level 4

As it was said before, there is a wide array of possible approaches to programming.  I hope we can make something that new teams could pick up and use as a template for improving their team.  Then each team can modify it for their uses.  After all, these are not FIRST official and you won‚Äôt be able to present levels 3 and 4 anyways.
